Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC CGI: Center for Dynamic Data Analytics (CDDA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
1069258 Rutgers University; Dimitris Metaxas
1069147 Arie Kaufman; SUNY at Stony Brook

The Center for Dynamic Data Analysis (CDDA) will focus on conducting innovative research and applications based on the collaborative efforts between the two universities and member companies in the emerging field of dynamic data analysis. The end result will be novel science, algorithms and applications that transform chaos into knowledge. Rutgers University (RU) and SUNY at Stony Brook are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with RU as the lead institution.

The proposed Center will investigate algorithms and potential solutions to analyze and visualize massive, complex, multidimensional and multi-scale dynamic data. The algorithm design will be tested, validated and improved based on the close collaboration and research between the two participating universities and industry. The participating universities have research and education programs whose strengths cover the technical scope of the center.

The proposed research projects will be useful to industry and homeland security, and the proposed Center will transform traditional research in computer science. Analysis and visualization of large-scale dynamic data will also become a new area of research for many graduate students. CDDA plans to have students spend time with the industrial affiliates in the form of summer internships and during the academic year so they can improve their skills. The participating universities also plan to leverage existing outreach programs at their institutions, and programs sponsored by the NSF, to encourage the participation of under-represented groups in the research..

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Disclaimer

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the PrincipalInvestigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed inthis Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation?NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Award Title: I/UCRC CGI: Center for Dynamic Data Analytics (CDDA)

Federal Award ID: 1069147

Report Submission Period: 03/01/2016 to 02/28/2017

During the past year Stony Brook CDDA carried out projects with members including CA Technologies,Mobileware, Northrop Grumman, Samsung and Softheon. All members were actively engaged in center activities. IAB meetings have been instrumental in enlarging the network of firms and other organizations with a stake in dynamic data analytics. CDDA leadership has invited potential industry members to IAB meetings in 2015 as guest speakers as well as other dynamic speakers to capture the attention and imagination of attendees and hopefully engaged them to return again.

A specialization in Data Science and Engineering has been developed and started enrolling graduate Computer Science students in September 2015.

In addition, we have been exploring developing collaborative relationships with universities which expressed interests in joining the CDDA as additional university sites. Both University of Virginia and University of North Carolina, Charlotte have submitted planning grant application to NSF to join the CDDA as additional university sites. University of Virginia will hold a planning workshop on April 4-5, 2016.

We continue to increase CDDA’s national visibility by participating in the NSF Northeast Big Data InnovationHubs Program.

Significant Results:

During the past year we have been working actively with our members, The collaboration with CA focuses on cloud computing, enterprise data management, network analytics and information security. We workedwith a new CDDA member, Mobileware, in developing mobile applications for Internet of Things (IoT) applications. The joint effort with Northrop Grumman is centered on large scale network analysis and anomaly detection. We are also working with Samsung to develop computer aided diagnostic tools using advanced imaging, visualization and analytics techniques. With Softheon, we are developing semantic based business process management and analytics tools for the healthcare industry. All of these activities fit into the CDDA nicely, as they address technical challenges in a broad spectrum of big data applications, including data management, security, modeling, analysis and visualization. Findings of these projects are submitted to various research conferences and journals. Preliminary results have been reported in talks and posters presented at the two CDDA workshops we organized this year as well as the 12th International Conference on Emerging Technologies for a Smarted World (CEWIT2015) and other conferences.

Key outcomes or other achievements:

Key outcomes of Stony Brook CDDA site during the past year include:

 

  • Increased membership fees from 150K to 208K (an 39% growth year over year)?
  • Exceeded the I/UCRC membership requirements (# of full members and the total amount)?
  • Held two workshops and IAB meetings with strong turnout and LIFE forms filled out and feedbackdiscussed?
  • Developed and distributed quarterly newsletters to IAB members and other companies which may have an interest to join the CDDA? and
  • Building momentum to expand the CDDA with two university partners, namely, University of Virginia and University of Carolina, Charlotte, submitting planning grant applications to join the center;
  • In addition to research support from companies such as Google, Facebook, and Yahoo, CDDAresearchers have collaborated with EMC Corporation, Adobe Systems, Cold Spring HarborLaboratories, VMWare, and Vanguard.

 

The Stony Brook CDDA is transforming the computer science curriculum by improving the applications taught in our classes as well as having our industry partners give lectures on the problems industry faces. A Specialization in Data Science and Engineering has been developed and started enrolling graduate Computer Science students in September 2015.

Our students also had the opportunity to work with our industrial partners in the form of summer internships and through the CDDA during the academic year to gain real world experience and improve their problem solving skills. Students involved in CDDA’s research activities have acquired in-depth knowledge and hands-on skills which benefit them in both their advanced studies and their future career. In particular, one of the CDDA companies, CA Technologies, has been operating an Innovation Center at CEWIT which employed over 60 students on multiple projects over the past year. Softheon and Mobileware have employed more than two dozens of undergraduate and graduate student interns throughout the academicyear.

CDDA also partnered with CEWIT and the New York City Data Science Academy in offering a verysuccessful, full-daytutorial on Big Data and Data Science Technologies at the 12th InternationalConference on Emerging Technologies for a Smarted World (CEWIT2015).
